author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Why Musk May Be Stuck
description: Twitter is in a good position to sue under a legal doctrine called specific performance, which allows courts to force a transaction to be completed, even if one of the parties wants out.
content: Elon Musk late last week finally followed through on his threat to try to pull out of his $44 billion deal to buy Twitter. The social media company promptly responded by saying it planned to sue. Most legal experts believe the law is strongly on Twitter’s side, assuming nothing explosive is revealed during trial. (Musk, in a tweet early this morning, seems to be relishing the prospect of forcing Twitter executives to hand over to the court information on how the company accounts for bots, his key complaint.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Conor Dougherty
title: Relief Eludes Many Renters as Fed Raises Interest Rates
description: As the central bank sharply increases borrowing costs, it could lock would-be home buyers into rentals and keep a hot market under pressure.
content: Rents have been rising swiftly across America for much of the pandemic era, and housing experts are warning that they could now receive a boost from an unlikely source: the Federal Reserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: ‘Stay and Fight’ Isn’t So Easy When a Red State Puts Your Child at Risk
description: When their home states are led by zealots, families face tough choices.
content: NASHVILLE — Last year, two families in Wilson County, Tenn., signed on as plaintiffs in a federal civil rights lawsuit challenging Tennessee legislation that prohibits transgender students from using bathrooms that align with their gender identities. But as WPLN News reported last week, both families have since left the state, believing their children would not be safe here long enough to see the lawsuit through. Now that the plaintiffs have moved away, a district judge has dismissed the suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rikki Novetsky, Mooj Zadie, Sydney Harper, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano and Dan Powell
title: On Abortion Laws, It All Goes Back to 2010
description: How a “red wave” led to restrictions at the state level that, in most cases, do not reflect the majority opinion of the states’ own citizens.
content: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, the court’s conservative majority argued it was simply handing the question of abortion to the states and their voters to decide for themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘White on White’ Review: American Grotesque
description: Robert Quillen Camp’s play, about an antiracist discussion group, starts out naturalistically, but then pivots, with bloody abandon, to the absurd.
content: “This orgy of white monstrosity must cease! Now! NOW!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Denver Broncos Add Condoleezza Rice to Ownership Group
description: Rice is the second Black woman to join the team’s new ownership group, alongside Mellody Hobson.
content: The Denver Broncos on Monday announced the addition of former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to the team’s new ownership group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Democrats Need to Start Playing Offense
description: Declaring a national day for abortion rights would send a strong message.
content: Over the past few weeks, I’ve received several messages from readers and friends about the need for hopeful alternatives in my work. This request, I believe, is a response to my main preoccupations in this space: homelessness, nursing homes, protests and the increasing failure of Democrats to reach working-class voters, especially immigrants. It’s true that my forecast for each of these issues is rather bleak, but I understand why readers might want some alternatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rajan Menon
title: India and the United States: Two Countries That Can’t Live With Each Other or Without Each Other
description: Meenakshi Ahamed’s “A Matter of Trust” traces the tangled, complicated and difficult relationship between two allies that are not quite friends.
content: A MATTER OF TRUSTIndia-US Relations From Truman to TrumpBy Meenakshi Ahamed
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Taunting Gunman and 78 Minutes of Terror
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 11, 2022.
content: “I’m not going to make it. I’m going to bleed out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: States With Abortion Bans Risk Losing Their Economic Edge
description: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has prompted Democratic governors to pitch their states as better alternatives for business.
content: As a group of conservative states enacted severe abortion restrictions last year, Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois sent letters to a handful of corporate executives with close ties to Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Zixu Wang
title: Three cities in China impose partial lockdowns as new cases are reported.
description: The cities of Xi’an, Lanzhou and Haikou set restrictions on several million residents. In Macau, the gambling hub, authorities shut casinos and ordered everyone to stay home.
content: At least three Chinese cities put in place partial lockdowns and the gambling hub of Macau shut its casinos for the second time since the start of the pandemic, as authorities tried to stamp out the latest coronavirus outbreaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalley Huang
title: What Is Delaware’s Court of Chancery and Its Role in Elon Musk’s Twitter Deal?
description: If Twitter sues Mr. Musk to force a sale of the company, the case is likely to end up at a 230-year-old court in Delaware.
content: A brewing legal battle over Elon Musk’s effort to terminate a $44 billion deal to buy Twitter will most likely land in a courtroom in Delaware. That’s where a 230-year-old court that is a prime venue for corporate battles may hear a case, should Twitter sue Mr. Musk to force a completion of the deal, as it is expected to do this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: ‘There’s Nothing’: Scarcity Deepens Desperation in Sri Lanka
description: The island nation was once an economic hope, with a growing middle class. Now many people are living on the edge, unable to buy even the basics.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The woman stood in line for more than 14 hours for a passport, desperate to escape the economic crisis engulfing Sri Lanka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Jan Ransom
title: Rikers Officer Fired After Latest New York City Jail Death
description: Elijah Muhammad, 31, had been held in the George R. Vierno Center for a month before he died in an incident that is now under review.
content: A 31-year-old man died on Sunday in a Rikers Island jail, prompting the immediate firing of a correction officer involved in the incident, city officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: The pandemic kept many children less active around the world, researchers find.
description: Pandemic shutdowns and restrictions led to a 20 percent drop in average daily physical activity among children and adolescents, a new analysis shows.
content: As children around the world stayed home, studied remotely and became more socially isolated during the coronavirus pandemic, they also became less physically active, according to a new review of almost two dozen studies that was published Monday in the medical journal JAMA Pediatrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Russia is seeking surveillance drones from Iran, a top Biden aide says.
description: The national security adviser said the U.S. believed Iran was preparing to train Russian troops imminently.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s national security adviser said on Monday that Russia is seeking hundreds of surveillance drones from Iran, including those capable of firing missiles, to use in the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Right to Travel in a Post-Roe World
description: In a concurring opinion last month, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh said the Constitution did not allow states to stop women from traveling to get abortions. But the issue is more complicated than that.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh signed the recent majority opinion that overruled Roe v. Wade. He also issued a 12-page concurring opinion, writing only for himself. He wanted to discuss, he wrote, “the future implications” of the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zixu Wang and Austin Ramzy
title: Security Forces in China Attack Protesters Seeking Frozen Funds
description: After a rare mass demonstration, bank depositors demanding their money back were beaten, kicked to the ground and dragged away in the city of Zhengzhou.
content: HONG KONG — A financial scandal in central China has touched depositors across the country, some of whom placed their life savings in four rural banks offering high rates of return, then found their funds frozen as investigators examined allegations of widespread fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: For Uvalde Families, a Call for Answers Grows Louder
description: At City Council meetings and at a protest on Sunday, the relatives of the slain children and teachers have shown their anger and frustration.
content: UVALDE, Texas — Kimberly Rubio and her husband, Felix, took the stage on Sunday evening at Uvalde Plaza next to City Hall while holding a photo of their slain daughter, Alexandria Aniyah Rubio, known as Lexi, and read aloud part of the mission statement of the Uvalde Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Surrounded by Survivors of Gun Violence, Biden Calls for More Action
description: The White House event was briefly interrupted by a protester, who demanded stronger efforts from Washington to restrict guns.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden welcomed hundreds of survivors and family members of victims of mass shootings to the White House on Monday to promote newly enacted bipartisan gun legislation, an event that showcased both the president’s desire to push for even more restrictive gun control measures and the political limitations that have held him back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Rail Strife Shadows Plans for Record British Open Crowd
description: About 290,000 fans are expected at St. Andrews for this year’s tournament. Whether they will be able to get there by train is a different matter.
content: EDINBURGH — For the 150th iteration of the British Open, organizers are expecting the thickest galleries in the competition’s history, with some 290,000 fans traipsing around to gawk at the Old Course at St. Andrews over the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Olympic Champion Mo Farah Says He Was Trafficked to U.K. as a Child
description: Farah, an accomplished distance runner, made the revelation in an upcoming documentary, saying it could put his citizenship at risk.
content: Mo Farah, the first British track and field athlete to win four Olympic gold medals, said in a stunning revelation for his country and sport that he had been trafficked to the United Kingdom as a child under a false name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Putin extends a fast-track Russian citizenship process to all Ukrainians.
description: The move indicated that Russia might seek to establish permanent control of Ukrainian territories currently occupied by Moscow’s forces.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday signed a decree offering a simplified path to Russian citizenship for all Ukrainians, an effort to broaden Moscow’s appeal and solidify its presence in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Text Your Friends. It Matters More Than You Think.
description: New research says most of us underestimate the power of the casual check-in.
content: Calling, texting or emailing a friend just to say “hello” might seem like an insignificant gesture — a chore, even, that isn’t worth the effort. Or maybe you worry an unexpected check-in wouldn’t be welcome, as busy as we all tend to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Senate Absences Snarl Democrats’ Plans for a Quick Return to Business
description: With two Democrats testing positive for the coronavirus and a third convalescing after a fall, the Senate floor is at a standstill, underscoring the fragility of the party’s bare-minimum majority.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, tested positive for the coronavirus on Sunday, forcing him into isolation just as the Senate was set to reconvene on Monday night after a two-week recess, and ahead of one of its last major work periods before the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Everything’s Trash’ and ‘The Rehearsal’
description: New shows from the idiosyncratic comedy creators Phoebe Robinson and Nathan Fielder debut on Freeform and HBO.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Contreras Brothers Join a Rare Fraternity as All-Star Starters
description: The National League’s starting catcher (Willson) and designated hitter (William) will join four other sets of brothers who have started an M.L.B. All-Star Game together.
content: When the National League takes the field for this year’s All-Star Game at Dodger Stadium on July 19, Willson Contreras will be behind the plate at catcher and his brother William will start at designated hitter. It will be the 92nd playing of the Midsummer Classic, but only the sixth in which brothers have started together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: Hochul’s Vow to Fix Albany’s Culture Finds an Unexpected Foe: Herself
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said she would usher in a “new era of transparency.” But critics, including the state comptroller’s office, said she has failed to do so.
content: ALBANY — In the last days of the 2022 legislative session, as the State Capitol was abuzz with frenzied pushes to strengthen gun control, abortion rights and environmental regulations, New York lawmakers received a jolting email.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Democrats Schedule Votes on Abortion Access, but Lack a Legislative Path
description: Democrats in Congress are under pressure to act after the Supreme Court’s decision. But with Republicans and at least one Democrat opposed in the Senate, the measures are all but certain to fail.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats in Congress, under pressure to take quick action in response to the Supreme Court’s decision striking down abortion rights, are planning to hold votes this week on legislation that seeks to preserve access to abortions in the post-Roe v. Wade era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: And the Next President Will Be …
description: Well, it won’t be Elon Musk.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Have I ever mentioned to you that I’m not an Elon Musk fan?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Russia seeks new soldiers.
content: Russian forces desperately need new soldiers. Already, the government is using what some analysts call a “stealth mobilization” to bring in new recruits without resorting to a politically risky national draft. “Russia has a problem with recruitment and mobilization,” said Kamil Galeev, an analyst specializing in Russia. “It is basically desperate to get more men using any means possible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Rivals Vying to Replace Johnson Are Diverse in Background, Not in Plans
description: The Conservatives running to be Britain’s prime minister include women and people of non-European descent, but they sound a lot alike: They like Brexit and want to cut taxes.
content: LONDON — Four are women. Six have recent forebears hailing from far beyond Europe — India, Iraq, Kenya, Mauritius, Nigeria and Pakistan. Of the three white men, one is married to a Chinese woman while another holds a French passport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Téa Kvetenadze
title: A Random Killing Erodes a New York Block’s Sense of Stability
description: John Edwards was a beloved fixture on his Bronx block and another unintended victim of the gun violence that has put many New Yorkers on edge.
content: For years, John Edwards held court from a plastic blue chair outside his basement home on Prospect Avenue in the Belmont section of the Bronx. He kept the sidewalk tidy, talked young people through their troubles, picked up scrap metal and helped neighbors with odd jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Among the Literary Lions, at Full Roar, in the 1980s
description: In “Circus of Dreams,” the literary editor John Walsh writes about the bookish life in London when Martin Amis, Ian McEwan, Jeanette Winterson and their generation were in the increasingly bright limelight.
content: In an essay for The New Republic in 2012, Martin Amis told what happened — or rather, what didn’t happen — when his first novel, “The Rachel Papers,” was published in 1973:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A Mystery: More Jobs Filled, but Lower Output
description: Productivity gains achieved during the pandemic have diminished as low-wage workers return en masse.
content: The U.S. economy is continuing to create a lot of jobs, but the growing work force isn’t producing a bigger gross domestic product. It’s worrisome, so what exactly is going on?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Bad Bunny’s ‘Un Verano Sin Ti’ Spends a Fourth Week at No. 1
description: Since its release, the Puerto Rican superstar’s album has earned the equivalent of 1.4 million sales and picked up 1.9 billion streams in the United States alone.
content: Back in May, the Puerto Rican superstar Bad Bunny released a new album, “Un Verano Sin Ti,” with just a few days’ notice (after teasing it for months). He is one of the world’s most popular performers on streaming services, so it was no surprise when “Un Verano Sin Ti” went straight to No. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: The Explosive Ambitions of Kate the Chemist
description: At the lecture halls of the University of Texas or on TV, Kate Biberdorf is working to catalyze more people into careers in science.
content: The dream is Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Peg Rails
description: The traditional peg rail is one of the simplest and most appealing kinds of storage you can add to a room. Here are five of the best.
content: For such a simple product, a peg rail can solve a surprising number of storage problems. It can easily hold a mountain of coats, as well as various other essentials — hats, bags, umbrellas, brooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Glenn Thrush
title: Hutchinson Testimony Jolts Justice Dept. to Discuss Trump’s Conduct More Openly
description: A key witness’s account helped accelerate a shift in the agency’s inquiry: Overt talk about Mr. Trump and his behavior had been rare, except as a motive for the actions of others.
content: WASHINGTON — For the past year and a half, the Justice Department has approached former President Donald J. Trump’s effort to overturn the 2020 election results with a follow-the-evidence strategy that to critics appeared to border on paralysis — and that limited discussions of his role, even inside the department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: He Fixed NASA’s Giant Space Telescope, Reluctantly
description: Gregory Robinson was enjoying another job when NASA persuaded him to take on an enormous astronomy project that was billions of dollars over budget and years behind schedule.
content: In 2018, the James Webb Space Telescope, the beleaguered project to build an instrument that could gaze back to the earliest stars in the universe, appeared to be going off the rails. Again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Benjamin Weiser
title: Chief Judge Resigns at Crucial Time for New York’s Top Court
description: Judge Janet DiFiore, whose legacy includes a sweeping opinion on gerrymandering, will leave at the end of August after more than six years on the court.
content: Janet DiFiore, the chief judge of the New York Court of Appeals, the state’s highest court, says she will step down at the end of August, even as lawmakers in Albany consider stronger laws on guns and abortion, measures at the heart of a national debate whose legality could be determined by the state judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Preserved Citrus From a Sicilian Institution
description: The Bronx-based company Gustiamo now imports bergamot, orange and lemon varieties from Caffè Sicilia in the town of Noto.
content: Caffè Sicilia in Noto, a Baroque town in the hilly southeast corner of Sicily, has been a destination since it opened in 1892. Now owned by Corrado Assenza, the fourth generation of the founding family, it is a resource for some of Sicily’s most treasured confections. Corrado follows the longstanding tradition of preserving citrus peels slowly, without additives, merely sugared in the final stage of production. Beatrice Ughi’s Bronx-based company, Gustiamo, now imports the bergamot, orange and lemon varieties, all in large slabs of peel rendered moist, fragrant and arrestingly fresh-tasting. Use them as you would candied fruits in baking, sliver them to season cocktails or use them to dress roast duck, seafood or even pasta. As a nibble, before you know it they’re gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Wright
title: A Glimpse Inside a Florentine Silk-Weaving Workshop
description: The Antico Setificio Fiorentino, which relies on looms from the 18th and 19th centuries, has been producing precious textiles since 1786.
content: In a quiet corner of the bohemian district of San Frediano, hidden behind an 18th-century iron gate that opens onto a whimsical wisteria-covered alleyway, lies a Florentine cultural treasure: the Antico Setificio Fiorentino, or Antique Florentine Silk Mill, which has been producing precious textiles since 1786.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Danai Gurira Makes a Sleek Supervillain of Richard III
description: At Shakespeare in the Park, athletic stamina and action-hero charisma muddy the meaning of a play about disability.
content: Richard of Gloucester may be the killingest character in Shakespeare, personally knocking off or precipitating the deaths of more than a dozen people who get in his way. To be fair, he does so over the course of three plays, while top competitors like Macbeth and Titus Andronicus have just one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Paradise Square’ Will Close on Broadway After Winning One Tony
description: The new musical was an unsuccessful comeback attempt by the storied producer Garth H. Drabinsky.
content: “Paradise Square,” a dance-rich Broadway musical about race relations in Civil War-era New York City, will close Sunday, after weeks trying to overcome persistently soft sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Crypto Is Crashing. Where Were the Regulators?
description: An anatomy materializes of a postmodern pyramid scheme.
content: When the Federal Reserve speaks, it speaks in Fedspeak. A pithy turn of phrase or a striking metaphor can all too easily turn into a headline, causing big market moves and a public backlash. So dry technical language and euphemisms are usually the way to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Lea Michele to Star in ‘Funny Girl’ After Beanie Feldstein’s Departure
description: The former “Glee” star will share the stage with Tovah Feldshuh, who will replace Jane Lynch as Fanny Brice’s mother, starting Sept. 6.
content: The actress Lea Michele will take over as Fanny Brice in the Broadway revival of “Funny Girl” in early September, the show said Monday, after Beanie Feldstein’s abrupt announcement that she would be leaving the role earlier than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: One Golfer Not Welcome at the British Open? Greg Norman.
description: Norman’s only major tournament victories came in Opens, but his role leading the Saudi-financed LIV Golf series has caused a rift with the R&A.
content: LONDON — It was only this spring that Greg Norman, who twice hoisted the claret jug as the winner of the British Open, sought a special dispensation to play in this week’s tournament at St. Andrews in Scotland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Raskin Brings Expertise on Right-Wing Extremism to Jan. 6 Inquiry
description: The Democrat from Maryland has been delving into the rising threat of white nationalism and white supremacy for five years. He will lead the inquiry’s hearing on the subject on Tuesday.
content: WASHINGTON — When Representative Jamie Raskin enters a Capitol Hill hearing room on Tuesday to lay out what the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack has uncovered about the role of domestic extremists in the riot, it will be his latest — and potentially most important — step in a five-year effort to crush a dangerous movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye, Kenneth Chang and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden and NASA Share First Webb Space Telescope Image
description: From the White House on Monday, humanity got its first glimpse of what the observatory in space has been seeing: a cluster of early galaxies.
content: In a brief event at the White House on Monday evening, President Biden unveiled an image that NASA and astronomers hailed as the deepest view yet into our universe’s past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Weissmann
title: Merrick Garland Should Investigate Trump’s 2020 Election Schemes as a ‘Hub and Spoke’ Conspiracy
description: The Justice Department needs to rethink its approach.
content: The tenacious work of the Jan. 6 committee has transformed how we think about the Jan. 6 rebellion. It should also transform the Justice Department’s investigation into efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: After a String of Student Deaths, Cambridge Opens an Inquiry
description: One of the deaths is confirmed to have been suicide and the others are suspected of being suicides. The university is working with the National Health Service to investigate.
content: LONDON — Cambridge University has opened an investigation into a string of student deaths, one of which has been confirmed to be suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Civilians Bear the Brunt
description: Russian strikes have killed, maimed and terrified residents across eastern Ukraine.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Kwame Onwuachi and Tilit Collaborate on a Playful Apron
description: The chef channeled his love for Pop-Art into a design that incorporates foods and New York City imagery.
content: The chef Kwame Onwuachi has transferred his taste for Pop-Art into an apron design that incorporates foods and New York City imagery for Tilit, a chef’s gear company. (There’s also a blunt, though censored, message to not label the wearer.) An avocado, a pretzel, a kettle grill, a taxi and more are pictured in a dense pattern on organic duck cotton canvas created with Tilit’s designers. The sturdy apron with a pocket comes in lavender, white or gray, and has a removable leather strap at the neck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Taste Dozens of Wines to Support Sommelier Scholarships
description: The two-hour event, held at Popina by the wine event company La Paulée, will also finance trips for young somms.
content: A talent for speed tasting (and accurate spitting) is what you’ll need to get through more than 75 Burgundies, Champagnes and Rhône wines in two hours in a Brooklyn backyard. The marathon fund-raising tasting, on Tuesday from 5:30 to 7:30, is all to benefit the nonprofit Sommelier Scholarship Fund created by La Paulée, the wine event company. It will include producers like Faiveley, Bouchard and Moreau-Naudet Burgundies; Gosset and Savart from Champagne; and Graillot and Gerin from the Rhône. It will also help finance trips for young somms. Food from Billy Durney of Hometown BBQ, Daniel Eddy of Winner and Chris McDade of Popina, the host restaurant, will be served.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Beanie Feldstein to Depart ‘Funny Girl’ Earlier Than Expected
description: The actress announced on Instagram that she would be leaving the musical at the end of July, two months earlier than previously announced.
content: Beanie Feldstein, the lead actress in the first Broadway revival of “Funny Girl,” announced on Instagram on Sunday night that she would be leaving the production at the end of this month, two months earlier than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti
title: Where Mantras Trump Medicine, Vaccines Are a ‘Violation’
description: The Baduy, an Indigenous group in Indonesia, believe that vaccinations are impure, and unnecessary, and that their beliefs protect them. To skeptics, they note their Covid death toll: zero.
content: KANEKES, Indonesia — When their ancestors warned them, through dreams and a bone-bitingly cold wind, to be careful, the community leaders of the Baduy people in Indonesia knew they needed to protect their villages from something bad that was on its way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany on Edge as Russian Gas Pipeline Goes Offline for Repair
description: Supplies via Nord Stream 1 dropped to zero as the pipeline began a 10-day maintenance period amid uncertainty over how long the shutdown would really last.
content: The flow of natural gas from Russia to Germany via a crucial undersea pipeline stopped on Monday, as the link went offline for a 10-day scheduled maintenance period, testing Europe’s resolve to wean itself off abundant Russian fuel supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Wimbledon Needs More Arthur Ashe Moments, On and Off the Court
description: Nick Kyrgios and Ons Jabeur brought a fresh diversity to the men’s and women’s singles finals.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — For the first time in nearly a half-century, a weekend at Wimbledon felt, and looked, different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Tanqueray Looks Back at Her Grand and Gritty New York Life
description: Stephanie Johnson went from burlesque nights in Times Square to internet stardom. “I did it my way and it worked,” she said.
content: Stephanie Johnson has had two moments of fame. The first came when she was a burlesque dancer who went by the stage name Tanqueray in the gritty Times Square of the 1960s and 1970s, a time when “10,000 men in New York City knew my name,” as she once put it. She re-entered the spotlight three years ago as an internet sensation after she shared candid tales of her life with Humans of New York, a digital franchise with millions of followers on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Oil companies oppose a windfall tax in Britain despite record profits.
description: Oil and gas companies say charging them a 25 percent tax on profits could deter future investment at a critical time for Britain.
content: With Britain engulfed in a political crisis and Boris Johnson’s administration winding down, oil industry executives are urging the government to make changes to a windfall tax measure aimed at curbing the ballooning profits of oil and gas companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kazin
title: Even if Republicans Outlaw Abortion, Americans Will Soon Rebel
description: Prohibition couldn’t even last 14 years. Will an abortion ban last that long?
content: A movement that seeks to compel Americans to live according to a stringent moral code may be most vulnerable when it succeeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Its Rivals Filled the Nets. England Showed It Can, Too.
description: A meeting of equally regarded teams ended with an 8-0 England victory and arguably the most surprising result of the women’s Euros.
content: BRIGHTON, England — As the goals rained in, first two in the first 15 minutes, then two more in quick succession, then two more on top of those, all before halftime, it was hard not to think England was sending a message.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Few Words From a Master Journalist
description: Francis X. Clines wrote thousands of lyrical, acutely observed articles for The New York Times. Here are excerpts from a few of them.
content: Among his postings as a foreign correspondent, Mr. Clines reported from Moscow as the Soviet Union was falling apart. In addition to a string of Page One articles chronicling the news, he found a perfect metaphor for the crumbling superpower in its airline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How California Is Preparing for a Surge in Out-of-State Abortion Patients
description: The state is shoring up resources to be the nation’s abortion refuge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Fans Love W.N.B.A. All-Stars, but Cast a Critical Eye on the League
description: Fans who traveled to Chicago to celebrate their favorite players called for the W.N.B.A. to improve. The players did, too.
content: CHICAGO — Benita Harrison-Diggs traveled from Virginia Beach to make a weekend out of the W.N.B.A. All-Star Game with friends. She remembered the excitement around the league’s “exceptional” inaugural season in 1997 and was hopeful that 2022 would match it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Kamila Hrabchuk and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russia Steps Up Attacks on Civilian Areas, Even With Advance Paused
description: Russian forces in eastern Ukraine are regrouping, with a new offensive expected, but they continue to rain death and destruction on cities and towns.
content: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — Over one town, an arc of fireballs burst and drifted down like fireworks, setting gardens and homes ablaze. In another, Russian missiles slammed into a five-story apartment block, shearing off a side of the building and killing at least 30 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Twitter’s stock falls further as doubts swirl over Elon Musk’s takeover.
description: Shares have lost a third of their value since April 25, when the company’s board accepted Mr. Musk’s offer.
content: Shares of Twitter fell more than 11 percent by the close of trading on Monday, as investors anticipated a potentially drawn-out legal battle between the social media company and Elon Musk over his move to scrap a deal to buy the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: An Anti-Trump Republican Group Is Back for the Midterms
description: The group, the Republican Accountability PAC, plans to spend at least $10 million to beat candidates who embrace Donald Trump’s false claims about the 2020 election.
content: Prominent conservatives who worked to oust Donald Trump in 2020 are back — with a plan to spend at least $10 million to defeat candidates who embraced the former president’s conspiracy theories about that election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A. Cerisse Cohen
title: For Millennials in Los Angeles, Bad Thoughts Arise
description: Nada Alic’s debut story collection pierces superficial appearances to access deeper human connection.
content: Throughout Nada Alic’s debut fiction collection, “Bad Thoughts,” sunny facades belie strange, dark interiors. The stories feature a privileged millennial milieu in Los Angeles with all its carefully observed trappings — neutral linens at a baby shower, destination bachelorette weekends, social media obsessions, alternative wellness practices and a chic, spare loft “furnished with gray modular furniture resembling life-size Lego pieces.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Francis X. Clines, Lyrical Writer for The Times, Dies at 84
description: He brought a literary sensibility to his widely admired work as a reporter, columnist and editorial writer, whether covering the streets of New York or the Troubles of Northern Ireland.
content: Francis X. Clines, a reporter, columnist and foreign correspondent for The New York Times whose commentaries on the news and lyrical profiles of ordinary New Yorkers were widely admired as a stylish, literary form of journalism, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: The Story of 2 Homeless Men and the Meaning of Friendship
description: A Times deputy managing editor discusses his tale of two immigrants who formed a special bond while surviving on the margins of New York City.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at yesterday’s cover story in the Metropolitan section: the tale of Tin Chin and Mo Lin, Chinese-speaking immigrants who met in a Brooklyn homeless shelter and became inseparable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Imagining an Exodus: ‘Ain’t No Mo’’ to Take Flight on Broadway
description: The play, by Jordan E. Cooper, is a biting comedy set in an America that offers to relocate Black citizens to Africa.
content: “Ain’t No Mo’,” an uproarious and piercing comedy that imagines a moment in which the United States offers to relocate Black people to Africa, will be staged on Broadway this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: A global deal to tax large corporations is delayed a year.
description: The organization overseeing the negotiations pushed back the rollout of new rules, a move that is expected to postpone the agreement until 2024.
content: The most ambitious tax overhaul in a century faced a new setback on Monday when the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which is overseeing the global negotiations, said that proposed rules for how the world’s largest companies would be taxed would not be unveiled until the middle of next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Albuquerque Police Investigate Teenager’s Death in Standoff
description: Brett Rosenau, 15, was found dead in a house that caught fire during a standoff between the police and a man wanted on a parole violation.
content: The police in Albuquerque said they were investigating whether their tactics during a standoff last week contributed to a house fire in which a teenager died, and called for patience from protesters who believe he was shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Carl Zimmer
title: The U.S. government will buy 3.2 million doses of Novavax’s Covid vaccine.
description: The vaccine has not yet been authorized but is expected to be soon.
content: The Biden administration announced on Monday that it would buy 3.2 million doses of a Covid-19 vaccine from the Maryland pharmaceutical company Novavax that is expected to soon receive authorization in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Museum of Food and Drink Holds Storytime
description: Joshua David Stein, a food writer, will tell stories about food in the backyard of Local Roots NYC.
content: The Museum of Food and Drink has scheduled a session for children featuring Kalamata’s Kitchen, a program that explores food with books, games and other items. In the backyard of Local Roots NYC, a market and cafe, Joshua David Stein, a food writer, will tell stories about food; he will be joined by Sarah Thomas, a former sommelier at Le Bernardin and a founder of Kalamata’s Kitchen. Snacks will be served.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Most Democrats Don’t Want Biden in 2024, New Poll Shows
description: With the country gripped by a pervasive sense of pessimism, the president is hemorrhaging support.
content: President Biden is facing an alarming level of doubt from inside his own party, with 64 percent of Democratic voters saying they would prefer a new standard-bearer in the 2024 presidential campaign, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll, as voters nationwide have soured on his leadership, giving him a meager 33 percent job-approval rating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Suspect in Abe Shooting Held a ‘Grudge.’ Scrutiny Falls on a Church.
description: The Unification Church, with links to conservative political parties worldwide, said Monday that the mother of the man charged in Shinzo Abe’s death was a member.
content: TOKYO — When Tetsuya Yamagami was arrested after the assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, he told the police he had “a grudge” against a “certain group.” But the authorities haven’t identified the organization or explained its connection to Mr. Abe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: The E.U. health authorities call for a second Covid booster for those 60 and older.
description: The recommendation came as fears rise over mounting cases and hospitalizations across Europe.
content: European Union health agencies recommended on Monday that people ages 60 and older receive a second booster shot of a coronavirus vaccine, as fears rise over mounting cases and hospitalizations across the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Dueling Weaknesses
description: The Times has released its first poll of the 2022 midterm cycle.
content: In 2016, when The New York Times’s pollsters asked Americans whether they planned to vote for Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump, more than 10 percent said they would not support either one. They said that they would instead vote for a third-party candidate or not vote at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kapil Komireddi
title: A Reckless Dynasty Has Brought Calamity to Sri Lanka
description: The Rajapaksas fall, and take Sri Lanka with them.
content: Gotabaya Rajapaksa came to be known as The Terminator for crushing Sri Lanka’s nearly three-decade Tamil insurgency in 2009 as a defense official during the presidency of his older brother, Mahinda Rajapaksa. Gotabaya’s reputation for decisiveness brought the siblings — pushed out of office in 2015 — back to power four years later after a series of Islamist suicide bombings stirred renewed fondness for their ruthless ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Page and John Amory
title: Is Society Finally Ready for Male Birth Control?
description: We are developing new hormonal contraceptives for men. Post-Roe, our work is more critical than ever.
content: Over 40 percent of the six million annual pregnancies in the United States are unplanned, according to the latest data available, and about one in five pregnancies ends in abortion. With the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade, and the resulting loss of access to safe abortion care for millions of Americans, it is more critical than ever to prevent unplanned pregnancies. The use of an effective method of contraception is the best way to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Declining Mental Health
description: The pandemic’s toll on our mental health is showing up in our medicine cabinets.
content: The pandemic’s true toll on our mental health won’t be known for some time, but we’re beginning to see some of the initial signs in our medicine cabinets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Gary Player Fears for the Old Course (and Probably Your Breakfast Order)
description: Player, who won nine majors during his celebrated career, talked with The Times ahead of the British Open, his favorite top-tier tournament of all.
content: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Surely, Gary Player could have long ago gotten away from being one of golf’s globe-trotting mascots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: The Business Lunch May Be Going Out of Business
description: Many upscale restaurants that catered to the nation’s downtown office crowd are canceling the meal, as remote work persists and business deals are sealed online.
content: WASHINGTON — Few people understand the power lunch better than Ashok Bajaj. The restaurateur began his career here in the waning days of Ronald Reagan’s presidency, when he opened the Bombay Club a short walk from the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Restaurants Face an Extortion Threat: A Bad Rating on Google
description: Emails sent to dozens of restaurants, including those with Michelin stars, threaten a barrage of one-star reviews unless owners pay.
content: In a new scam targeting restaurants, criminals are leaving negative ratings on restaurants’ Google pages as a bargaining chip to extort digital gift cards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Largest-ever SPAC will return $4 billion to investors after failing to complete a deal.
description: The billionaire behind it, Bill Ackman, said he was “unable to consummate a transaction that both meets our investment criteria and is executable.”
content: Two years after raising the largest-ever special purpose acquisition company, or SPAC, the billionaire Bill Ackman has concluded that he will be unable to do a deal that meets its needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Alexandra Stevenson
title: China’s Economy Stumbles in the Fog of Covid War
description: Even if the country avoids new lockdowns of big cities, question marks over the pandemic and policy direction are dogging efforts to revive growth.
content: China’s economic engine has shuddered in recent months, hurt by lockdowns imposed to curb the spread of Covid. Housing sales sagged. Many shops and restaurants in some cities shuttered, some maybe for good. Youth unemployment climbed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Into the Woods’ Review: Do You Believe in Magic?
description: The Encores! revival of this fairy-tale musical, with songs by Stephen Sondheim, arrives on Broadway with its humor, wonder and humanity intact.
content: After the woods and the wolf and the dark and the knife, Little Red Riding Hood has learned a thing or two. In the first act of “Into the Woods,” while modeling a cloak made from the wolf’s pelt, she shares her wisdom. Be prepared, she advises in “I Know Things Now.” Watch out for strangers. Stephen Sondheim’s bone-dry lyrics supply one more maxim: “Nice,” Little Red concludes, “is different than good.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 11, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 11, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Does Public Art Have an Afterlife?
description: Public artworks have the power to uplift a city. Sometimes they end up in a museum, but other times in a dumpster.
content: Pamela Council set a deadline and said a prayer. It had been nearly seven months since the artist’s monument to survivors of the pandemic first appeared in Times Square, with its carapace of 400,000 hand-painted acrylic nails enshrining a bubbling fountain where visitors could reflect on persevering through Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: In a Time of Conflict, Ukraine Entrepreneurs Make War Their Business
description: From costume makers to consultants, fashion brands to uniform manufacturers, Ukrainian ventures have switched to producing goods to help wage war.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Yuriy Zakharchuk once dreamed up combat costumes for the stage, designing everything from medieval armor to space battle suits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Dimond
title: Inside Brazil’s 40-Year Rise to Global Surfing Dominance
description: This generation of Brazilian surfers is so dominant, so undeniable, that it has earned a nickname: the Brazilian Storm.
content: Under a brilliant Brazilian sun, as he rode across a perfect peeling wave, the professional surfer Filipe Toledo thumped his chest and shouted toward the beach. Toledo, 27, who grew up around 250 miles west of this stretch of sand, had just won his second World Surf League championship tour event of the year. The win, in Saquarema, Brazil, cemented his place as the top-ranked male surfer in the world, and he was one big step closer to winning the men’s world championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Toxic and Ineffective: Experts Warn Against ‘Herbal Abortion’ Remedies on TikTok
description: Amid the fear and confusion around abortion options across the country, some on social media have suggested taking herbs. But experts urge caution.
content: If you were scrolling through TikTok in the days after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June, you might be forgiven for thinking that you could give yourself an abortion by walking over to Whole Foods and eating a handful of parsley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Ukrainian Medic’s Months in Russian Cell: Cold, Dirty and Used as a Prop
description: Yulia Paievska was already well known in Ukraine when she was captured, but the trauma she describes has made her a symbol of bravery and sacrifice.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — During the siege of Mariupol, in southern Ukraine, Russians pounded the city with artillery and blocked civilian escape routes, creating one of the worst humanitarian crises of the war. As Ukrainian soldiers holed up in the Azovstal steel plant, the medic Yulia Paievska took on the dangerous work of evacuating families from a city under constant assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: The Question You Didn’t Know Needed Answering: Are Gophers Farmers?
description: Researchers suggest that root cropping by the small rodents could be the first case of nonhuman mammalian farming.
content: There are probably a few things that come to mind when you think of farmers. To list a few: overalls, straw hats, tanned forearms; bails of hay, tractors, seeds. All very farmer-friendly. What about fur, whiskers and large front teeth? Probably not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Ryan
title: The Race for a New Conservative Leader Is On. Not So Fast.
description: Are Britons supposed to simply forget what just happened?
content: It is customary, when someone is near death, to reflect on the life that person lived: Was time spent wisely, or wasted? Were good deeds done, or harm caused? It is much the same with a political death. As Boris Johnson’s government gasps its final breaths, many of us are reflecting on how this prime minister and his colleagues have used almost three years in power and the damage they have wrought. Not the candidates for the new Conservative leader, though; they’re ready to move on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Joe Biden Is Too Old to Be President Again
description: He beat Trump. Now we need someone to beat Trumpism.
content: I can’t help feeling very sorry for Joe Biden. He’s wanted to be president for most of his life, first running 34 years ago. Had his son Beau not died in 2015, Biden might have entered the Democratic primary then; as vice president he would have been a favorite and likely would have beaten Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Stewart
title: Fried Okra, Beyond the Batter
description: The classic Southern dish does more than just nourish: It tells a bigger story of the Black American cooks who have preserved its legacy, while creating their own versions.
content: For the born-and-bred Southerner, few culinary experiences rival the intense satisfaction of biting into perfectly fried okra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Remy Tumin
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.6 Million Homes in California
description: A Norwegian-style chalet in Bear Valley, a two-bedroom townhouse in Malibu and a brand-new four-bedroom home in Oakland.
content: Inspired by a 14th-century Norwegian farmhouse on display at a Scandinavian museum, the current owner built this house using wood from old-growth redwood trees and hired Norwegian artisans to do much of the interior detailing. The location, in the Sierra Nevada, attracts skiers looking for powdery snow and challenging slopes. Bear Valley is considered more remote than ski areas closer to Lake Tahoe, and many residents use snowmobiles to get around in the winter. During the summer, the scenic hiking trails are a big draw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Department Taps Oregon Official to Run Troubled Bureau of Prisons
description: The bureau has long been plagued by health and safety problems, physical and sexual abuse, corruption and turnover in the top management ranks.
content: WASHINGTON — Colette S. Peters, the longtime director of the Oregon Department of Corrections, has been tapped to lead the chronically mismanaged and understaffed federal Bureau of Prisons, according to two people familiar with the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Gerald W. McEntee, Union Leader With Political Clout, Dies at 87
description: He made the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees an electoral force in a time of Republican hostility to organized labor.
content: Gerald W. McEntee, the longtime president of one of the country’s largest public employee labor unions, died on Sunday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: A Year After Mass Protest, Cubans Face Stark Choice: ‘Prison or Exile’
description: Thousands of Cubans took to the streets last July protesting economic misery. A year later, hundreds are in jail and the financial crisis has only worsened.
content: MEXICO CITY — One year after Cubans took to the streets in one of the largest protest movements since the Communist government took power six decades ago, hundreds of demonstrators are languishing in prison while tens of thousands have fled repression and destitution on the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Whitney Is Soft on Hot Dogs
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art sells Yuki Matsuo’s hand-sewn foods for its shop.
content: The artist Yuki Matsuo, whose specialty is the intersection of food and design, has been hand-sewing stuffed fabric interpretations of various edibles, mostly meats, since 2005 for her company Yuki & Daughters. (She’s in something of a tradition: Think of the sculptor Claes Oldenburg and his giant soft BLT.) The Whitney Museum of American Art has been selling her pieces since it moved downtown in 2015, and now offers her fabric hot dogs. They are about six inches long and come with assorted toppings. Other designs include kielbasa, kosher salami, a pretzel and a black-and-white cookie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Hamptons Gets a Fancy New Food Store in L’Épicuriste
description: The store appeals to today’s home cooks with shopping lists that might include imports like ponzu with yuzu, truffled vegetables and more.
content: Years ago serious cooks in the Hamptons had more limited resources than they do today. Nonetheless, there remain gaps and filling them is the mission of an airy new gastronomic boutique, L’Épicuriste in Bridgehampton, N.Y. A shopping list that includes Japanese Kewpie mayonnaise, ponzu with yuzu, truffled vegetables and sauces, Moroccan spices, French pâtes de fruit and lovely gift boxes of Portuguese tinned sardines can easily be completed from its shelves. After living in the area during Covid, Charles de Viel Castel, a French-born financier, jewelry designer and entrepreneur, decided to fill a need he saw for products he could not find locally. His shop also sells baguettes from Armin & Judy, a nearby restaurant, and flower arrangements from the local florist Missi Flowers. The store is adjacent to a sliver of a market for baked goods and sandwiches from Pierre’s, a French restaurant, but Mr. de Viel Castel said the two shops seem to complement each other, not compete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Bank Protests in China
description: Plus Ukrainian civilians bear the brunt of Russia’s war and new details after Shinzo Abe’s death.
content: Security forces attacked as many as a thousand protesters who were trying to withdraw their money from four rural banks in Henan Province this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Mike Isaac
title: How Elon Musk Damaged Twitter and Left It Worse Off
description: Mr. Musk swooped in and exposed Twitter’s lack of business and financial prospects. After criticizing the company’s weaknesses, he now wants to back out of buying it.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Twitter was a runner-up social media company. It never grew to the size and scale of a Facebook or an Instagram. It simply muddled along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez and Ivan Penn
title: Texans Warned to Reduce Electricity Use Amid Fear of Rolling Blackouts
description: About 50 million people in the United States were under heat warnings or advisories over the weekend. The heat index was forecast to soar past 100 degrees Fahrenheit on Monday in about half of Texas.
content: Texas’ electricity regulator warned residents and businesses to reduce the amount of power they use on Monday as the heat index was forecast to soar above 100 degrees Fahrenheit, putting a strain on the state’s grid and potentially leading to rolling blackouts across the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Kate Kelly
title: F.D.A. to Weigh Over-the-Counter Sale of Contraceptive Pills
description: The first U.S. application for sale of a nonprescription birth control pill has taken on new meaning after the Supreme Court decision ending the constitutional right to abortion.
content: WASHINGTON — More than 60 years after the approval of oral contraceptives revolutionized women’s sexual health, the Food and Drug Administration has received its first application for a birth control pill sold over the counter — just as the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has put access to contraception more squarely at the heart of the clash over reproductive rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: PGA Tour’s Fight With LIV Golf Reaches Justice Department
description: The Justice Department is investigating the PGA Tour for anticompetitive behavior in its dealings with the breakaway LIV Golf series.
content: The conflict upending men’s professional golf spread to a new setting with the Justice Department investigating the PGA Tour for anticompetitive behavior in its dealings with the breakaway LIV Golf series, a tour spokeswoman confirmed Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: We’re Not Asking for the Moon
description: Millennials, on their very real fears about money.
content: Millennials, on their very real fears about money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama
title: Inside the Amazon Journey That Left a Journalist and an Activist Dead
description: Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira set off deep into the Amazon to meet Indigenous groups patrolling the forest. Then they vanished.
content: Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira set off deep into the Amazon to meet Indigenous groups patrolling the forest. Then they vanished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Why So Many Children of Immigrants Rise to the Top
description: The American Dream is more about “where” than “who.”
content: The American Dream is more about “where” than “who.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Celebrating Eid, and Yemen, in New York
description: Yemeni Americans gathered in New York City to celebrate Eid al-Adha and to pay homage to Yemen’s beauty and culture, often forgotten amid a devastating war.
content: Yemeni Americans gathered in New York City to celebrate Eid al-Adha and to pay homage to Yemen’s beauty and culture, often forgotten amid a devastating war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Jerrod Carmichael Was Scared of Coming Out. He Still Is.
description: “I want the love, desperately,” says the comedian, “but not at the cost of not talking about it because that makes me hate myself.”
content: “I want the love, desperately,” says the comedian, “but not at the cost of not talking about it because that makes me hate myself.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: $1.6 Million Homes in California
description: A Norwegian-style chalet in Bear Valley, a two-bedroom townhouse in Malibu and a brand-new four-bedroom home in Oakland.
content: A Norwegian-style chalet in Bear Valley, a two-bedroom townhouse in Malibu and a brand-new four-bedroom home in Oakland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Iran Prepares to Supply Russia With Surveillance Drones, U.S. Says
description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, said that Russia was seeking hundreds of surveillance drones from Iran, including those capable of firing missiles, to use in the war in Ukraine.
content: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, said that Russia was seeking hundreds of surveillance drones from Iran, including those capable of firing missiles, to use in the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Reveals First Image From James Webb Space Telescope
description: The image was hailed by NASA and astronomers as the deepest view yet into our universe’s past.
content: The image was hailed by NASA and astronomers as the deepest view yet into our universe’s past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Parkland Victim’s Father Disrupts Biden’s Remarks on Gun Bill
description: President Biden’s address on newly enacted bipartisan gun legislation was interrupted by Manuel Oliver, whose son was killed in the 2018 Parkland, Fla., school shooting.
content: President Biden’s address on newly enacted bipartisan gun legislation was interrupted by Manuel Oliver, whose son was killed in the 2018 Parkland, Fla., school shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: A no-recipe recipe for charred cabbage slaw, to accompany whatever you’re grilling.
content: Good morning. I’ve taken to throwing a whole head of cabbage onto the grill a few minutes after I’ve lighted the fire, so that by the time the wood’s burned into coals and I’m ready to cook my protein, the vegetable is blackened and charred all over.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Biden Run Again in 2024?
description: Readers weigh his job performance and age and offer contrasting opinions. Also: A Capitol policeman’s Jan. 6 account; ectopic pregnancies after Roe.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
